text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today 
we're gonna make a dish that's pretty hard

to find in Thailand these days people don't make 
it much anymore but in Thai restaurant overseas

many of them still serve it it's a dish called 
swimming Rama or in Thai pra ram long song now

it's a dish made of a bed of bright green Morning 
Glory or water spinach topped with tender slices

of pork and a rich red curry peanut sauce it's 
so delicious and the reason why we call it Rama

is because Rama the Hindu god in Thailand is shown 
to be green even though of you Google Image drama

most of the images are gonna be blue which I don't 
understand but that is not what we're concerned

with right now this dish is super delicious easy 
let's get started so let's start with the protein

this dish is typically made with pork but you can 
definitely do some chicken breast if you'd like

that'll be really good I've got some pork loin 
here I want something lean because the sauce

will be quite rich and I'm gonna marinate it with 
some fish sauce and I'm also gonna add some water

again I like to add some water to lean meat when 
marinating because the pork will absorb all that

turning it's super juicy a little bit of oil just 
to you know allow them to slide past each other

more easily so they're not clumping together so 
much and now I am also going to velvet my pork

which is a technique I've used before in my garlic 
lime pork recipe I'll make a link to that video

right here but it's basically creating a film 
of a coating around the pork that keeps all the

juices in when you cook it so I'm gonna do that 
by adding some cornstarch and because this dish

has quite a heavy sauce I can be a little more 
heavy-handed with the velvetine compared to my

lime pork recipe there we go looks like a lot of 
liquid right now do not worry the pork over time

will absorb all of that in and that is the secret 
to juicy tender pork so that needs at least 20

minutes all righty so I'm gonna make basically a 
standard classic red curry starting with reducing

a little bit of coconut milk bring that to a boil 
let it DUS until it's nice and thick and oily all

right so once the coconut milk is nice and thick 
like that I'm gonna add my red curry paste which

I'm just using store-bought for this get that 
mixed up and get it all frying in the coconut

oil and I find it helpful to add the curry paste 
when the coconut milk has introduced too much

because it gives you a lot of liquid to help 
loosen the paste up and I'm gonna keep frying

that until I start seeing coconut oil seeping 
out around the edges of the curry paste which

you can see happen right about now so now and 
that's happening you know the spices and herbs

are so frying in that coconut oil that doesn't 
happen for you don't worry about it's not too

big of a deal it does depend on the coconut milk 
itself now I'm gonna add the rest of my coconut

milk and I'm gonna add some of the seasoning 
in right now so some palm sugar a little bit

more than you might do with a regular red curry 
this sauce is super thick and it's sort of like

a salty and sweet kind of sauce I'm also gonna 
add some fish sauce of course now the amount of

fish sauce entirely depends on your curry pace 
so be very careful if you do store-bought paste

it can be quite salty so go easy on it and a 
little bit of sourness to balance all that out

I got some tamarind I'm gonna let that come 
to a simmer allow the flavors to mix in the

sugar to dissolve and all that stuff meanwhile 
let's deal with the peanuts so this is a peanut

sauce peanut sauce but not you know one of those 
creamy looking peanut sauce it's got texture and

character so right here I got some roasted 
peanuts and I always roast my own peanuts

I never buy roasted peanuts cuz who knows how 
long it's been roasted and it's just never as

fresh never as tasty and you can just easily 
do it in the oven that's gonna go in my food

processor right here this is optional but I've 
seen some recipes to it and I like adding it is

some toasted white sesame seeds I'm gonna also add 
that to the food processor you do not want this to

become peanut butter you want some grittiness 
some textures so you just want like coarse meal

yeah not so good right about there and back to 
the sauce now I'm gonna add all the peanuts and

the sesame seeds and at this point the sauce 
is basically done but you want it to simmer

for about 10 minutes just to allow all the flavors 
to mingle for the peanuts and the curry sauce to

become one that looks perfect you see a little 
bit of that red coconut oil floating to the top

just perfect I'm just gonna turn this off for 
now and give it a taste and also look at the

consistency it should be not too thick not too 
runny like a nice rich gravy okay now let's see

mmm perfect salty sweet and just a little hint of 
tartness to balance oh that's good and you want

the seasoning to be strong cuz the pork and the 
spinach is not gonna have too much flavor so now

that's done you can keep this for days also so if 
dealt with the park with dealt with the sauce and

now we're gonna deal with the Rama which is the 
green part now in Thailand we use boom which is

water spinach also known as Morning Glory I can't 
get that here right now sometimes I can but not

right now so spinach regular spinach will work 
just fine it's a ton of spinach but trust me it

will wilt to nothing okay so you all you need a 
lot of spinach for this so I'm just gonna simply

blanch it in boiling water I did put a little 
bit of oil in the water so that wouldn't I take

the spinach out it gets the oil it gets a little 
bit shiny and beautiful I'm gonna put them all

in ten seconds just to wilt that's it okay make 
sure you shake up as much water as you can and

then up onto a plate and now the pork which now 
looks like this see how much all the liquid has

been absorbed that is exactly what we are looking 
for I want to make sure I put the pork in my spot

first make sure the waters on a full full boil 
I dropped the park in and I just help it along

a little bit by stirring it splitting it apart 
and this will not take long it'll take just 30

seconds depending on how how much pork you're 
doing and that's it Park is done now putting

it together so you definitely want to have rice 
with this it's a very rich dish and sometimes in

Thailand it'll come as a single dish meal where 
you get a plate of rice with it on the side okay

so I've got that right here some rice now you want 
to put down your rama mmm what a great way to eat

lots of vegetables and so the idea is you make a 
bed and a little bit of pork or chicken whatever

you're using and here's the highlights the rama 
is now so women in sauce by the way long song

in Thai actually is more like bathing not quite 
swimming but minor details you can garnish it with

a little extra sesame seeds just so people know 
that there's some of that in there and that is it

how easy is that and you want to keep extra sauce 
on the side so you can pour more if you need to

all that pork is so tender mmm there's no 
better way to eat your greens than dousing

it in a red curry peanut sauce I'm telling you 
it's rich and creamy and the spinach is there

to balance it at that pour I'm telling you that 
velvety is so worth the effort and the time so

tender and this if you choose a curry paste it's 
not too spicy would be a great dish for kids a

great way to get them to eat more greens so I 
hope you give this a try the recipe as always

will be on Hawkeye kitchen calm when you make it 
send me a photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram

and if you haven't subscribed to the show make

like this and make sure you click that little
